chapter.title: Edited Volumes and Contributions to Edited Volumes
chapter.para: An edited volume typically does not have an author, but one or more editors, a title, a place and time of publication and an extent in number of pages or volumes.
An edited volume can be part of a series.

If "articles" are publications that occur inside periodicals, edited volumes consist of "edited volume contributions." An edited volume contribution has one or more authors and a title, and then it occurs inside an edited volume. You see the title of the edited volume, its editor(s), its place and time of publication, and the location of the contribution inside the edited volume.
The same three-division structure of a book inside a series applies.

ul.li: Carr, Anne, and Douglas J. Schuurman. "Religion and Feminism: A Reformist Christian Analysis." In Religion, Feminism, and the Family, edited by Anne Carr and Mary Stewart Van Leeuwen, 11-32. Louisville, KY: Westminster John Knox Press, 1996.

Demos, John. "Real Lives and Other Fictions: Reconsidering Wallace Stegner's Angle of Repose." In Novel History: Historians and Novelists Confront America's Past (and Each Other), edited by Mark C. Carnes, 132-45. New York: Simon and Schuster, 2001.

chapter.para: An edited volume may be part of a series: A contribution occurs within an antholgy that occurs within a series. On the "Container" tab for a contribution to an edited volume, you are therefore able to record the title of the series that the edited volume belongs to, and its location within the series.
